displayed_text: Patient: Every six months. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: I thought it was, I thought it was longer than that, but okay. Doctor: And then once we get a few years out beyond that, once we get out to five years, then we’ll start making it every year. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But after, the first year, every three months and then after that two to five years every six months, and then after that if everything stays okay then once a year. Patient: Because I take this serious. Doctor: Okay I can see that. Patient: I take this very, very, very serious. Doctor: The whole thing and I’m glad.

Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: So those are the two things that we’re really looking for. You also could say I also don’t want to do this anymore; I don’t like my numbers. You know I still have to get the pictures just to prove okay you came off because you don’t like being on the drug. You came off because your PSA was rising, you know it’s typically from a protocol perspective, he’s coming off because he’s feeling worse, his scan’s worse. Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s coming off because his scans are worse and his PSA is higher. Patient: Right. And I don’t have Doctor: So I’m comfortable going another month because I know that scans and by your lab tests and what you’ve told me about how you feel. And my sense is you should stay the course. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in the past you know we talked about the backup plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: What will we do - the day that I say hey, you know this isn’t working or you say I don’t want to do this anymore. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, We checked, you know, the one, the new therapy setting still where you live at. Patient: Um, hum.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

displayed_text: Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: But we do need to get you on that XGEVA that we had talked about. Family Member: Yeah chickles]]. Doctor: And you know every time. So today I have to see if they’re ready with it because then we might as well do that injection today. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because that is what most effected in countering both bone metastasis as well as the the- Family Member: Right. Patient: But if you’re not ready today I can get that back home too. Doctor: -bone weakness. Yeah you can. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: With a prescription. I was reading up on the prostate cancer in the bone and they recommended not – a diet low in calcium for that. Do you know anything about that? Doctor: No I think for a while people were maxing out and taking crazy high amounts of calcium. So that is not recommended because they actually found a worse outcome with that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So that one, let’s back off first of all to once a day. Patient: Oh, don’t… take it just once? Doctor: Just once in the morning. Patient: I’m gonna need a refill. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think so. Doctor: On that one? Patient: Right, but the ones do you remember… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but those though they don’t agree with you huh? The effects are… Patient: Yeah, the ones you gave me before that I think it was for… Doctor: The Megnace. Patient: Yeah I think that was for you know for throwing up or something like that. I take them because I took them and then it always worked. Like when I be feeling like nauseous I’ll throw up, I’ll take one of them and then I I cool down. But them other ones they

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have to sort it out by tomorrow because it’s you know technically Monday’s not a holiday but most people are taking off. Patient: Well I’m thinking it’s Tuesday. Doctor: Yeah that’s why I’m saying it’s got to be a week because you’ve got to fourth and the third is mostly a lot of people are off. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that leaves basically Friday and Wednesday. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?
DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years. Doctor: Bye guys. I’m happy you can get Family Member: Bye.

Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her. Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there. Doctor: So same thing, I would just bring a pair of gloves, your own towels and then you wipe and just get a bag that you throw off the stuff. You know what's hard is toddlers get into everything. And you just can't help it. They're curious. Family Member 1: Well, it wouldn't be just for the toddler. Like we all use the main bathroom. There's the upstairs. She's still in diapers, so she has where she not trained yet. Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. So you you get one of those Clorox thingy that you pull out. Patient: Yeah. I know.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. So, it would be something that again if you’re trying to avoid chemotherapy, here’s something that I could try. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s, uh, uh, the third option of a trial, so, is chemotherapy plus vitamin C, a phase one study. The other study would be that we would have to check a blood test on you, uh, that if you came back as AR-V7 positive. And I’d have to see if we’ve already done that for you in the past.

Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Exact lesion things like that because I really don’t know exactly which lesions would be good for that. Definitely ask about there is a procedure called kyphoplasty which can stabilize the spine. Patient: Hypo? Doctor: Kypho, kypho. K-Y-P-H-O and you know that’s something also to uh explore with neurosurgery. Okay? So um… Patient: Yeah I I’m not too anxious to have them go in there if it’s not gonna help me. Because I can live the way I am. Doctor: Yeah. I mean I wouldn’t have surgery if it’s not – if it’s unlikely to help for sure… Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Depending on and the changes if they’re more than fifty percent – Patient: I don’t know chuckles]]. Doctor: - I’m okay with trying for it. Family Member: So what was that kaypo? Doctor: K-Y-P-H-O-P-L-A-S-T-Y. Kyphoplasty.

Patient: Okay. Okay Doctor V____. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I’m I’m doing anything you want me to. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I’m good. Doctor: Okay so we’ll be back with all that paperwork and stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds)

Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know?

Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Patient: No problem. Doctor: But, I cannot be putting you on medications and then leaving you with whatever you’re dealing with. Okay. Just like that.

Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yes, I know, my family doctor, same thing. Doctor: Yeah. So, I think you have to sign signature of patient here, right here. Patient: Okay Alright. Doctor: So use that and then date it. That’s right. Family Member: If he does the chemo or radium Doctor: Yeah

Family Member: It’s still two years. So you don’t gain any time. Doctor: We don’t think so. Patient: What if we had castrate level Doctor: Quite frankly, we’re too nervous to you know; the first thing we’re trying to do is cure you. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And uh they were pretty; um, the lab studies were done in two years were sort of a minimum time in this setting. Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Doctor: Yeah and we give the chemo and the super hormones for three months. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then give you about time to recover about six to eight weeks later. Then we do the radiation, uh which puts you at about sort of eight months, you know out, so then you’d have another; it’s a total of two years of hormones. Patient: Okay and then how frequently will my PSA be tested while I’m doing the chemo? Doctor: Every month.
